title.narrative: Support COVID 19 response in Shahrak-e-Sabz and Clinic Area/Shaidayee Informal Site in Herat

description.narrative:
The proposed intervention aim is to prevent and mitigate against COVID-19 transmission and impact on Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) in Herat province. Afghanistan already faces major gaps within its health care system and preventing the spread of COVID-19 is critical to saving lives and reducing the burden on healthcare infrastructure and recourses. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a global pandemic on March 11, 2020. As of April 7th 2020, 1.384 million cases of COVID-19 have been confirmed and 78,917 deaths have been reported across the world. In Afghanistan, Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) data indicates that 521 people across 23 provinces are confirmed to have the virus and 14 people have died. Herat remains the epicenter for the crisis with 80% of the total registered cases in the country.
Afghanistan is likely to be significantly affected due to its weak health system and limited capacity to deal with major disease outbreaks. Afghanistan’s close proximity to Iran and the high numbers of Afghan returnees from Iran, puts the country at heightened risk, with tens of thousands of people and commercial movements across the border from each day. High internal displacement, low overall vaccination rates, prevalence of comorbidity among vulnerable populations and weak health, water and sanitation infrastructure, create a context in which vulnerability to COIVID-19 transmission and infection is high. Herat province has the highest number of COVID-19 confirmed cases in Afghanistan and hosts a large IDP population. WVA is already operational in Herat IDP settlements through the existing awards. The proposed intervention will focus on three areas, 1) Active Community Screening, 2) Risk Communication and Awareness Raising and 3) Support existing health service delivery points including isolation wards and hospitals
The medical waste will be disposed in coordination with the WHO, BPHS implementing NOGO, DEWS, UNICEF and other relevant Stakeholders and make sure no medical waste remain in the area. The disposition of the waste will be done in an area outside of the residential areas recommended by DOPH to make sure this intervention has no negative impact on the environment.
WV has already coordinated with WHO help promotion focal point and Religious affairs. The 200 faith leaders will be trained upon the approval of the proposed project. WV is already working with the department of Haj and religious affairs and the selection of the 200 faith leaders will be done in coordination with the Haj and religious affairs.
